questions.text: In the given image, what is the action of the highlighted muscle?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle is temporalis, and the action of temporalis is elevation of the mandible. The temporalis raises the jaw, which closes the mouth and brings the teeth closer together. Note- All muscles of mastication produce jaw elevation except lateral pterygoid. All muscles of mastication cause protraction of jaw except temporalis. Primary action is elevation.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 677

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of occlusion of the artery supplying the marked area?
questions.solution:
The marked area is the paracentral lobule.
 
  • This region controls voluntary urination and defecation as well as the movements of the contralateral lower leg and perineum.
  •  Hence, blockage of the artery feeding the paracentral lobule can result in perianal analgesia, urinary incontinence, and rectal incontinence but not apraxia.
Apraxia results from damage to dominant parietal lobe. 


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 512
https://radiopaedia.org/articles/paracentral-lobule

questions.text: Identify the highlighted nerve in the given cranial cavity section.
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image of cranial cavity is oculomotor nerve. It is the third cranial nerve. 
  • Four of the extraocular muscles are innervated by it: the superior, inferior, medial, and inferior oblique muscles. Moreover, it carries parasympathetic fibers that relay in the ciliary ganglion.
  • The nerve begins at the midbrain, medial to the cerebral peduncle's crus, and travels along the lateral cavernous sinus wall before splitting into superior and inferior divisions that pass below the trochlear and ophthalmic nerves.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 391,563,566

questions.text: Which layer is marked in the given histological section?
questions.solution:
The marked layer in the given histological section of the retina is the inner plexiform layer.

The inner plexiform layer comprises a dense reticulum of fibrils formed by interlaced dendrites of RGCs and cells of the inner nuclear layer.

Layers of retina:-
1. Inner limiting membrane
2. Nerve fiber layer (NFL)
3. Ganglion cell layer
4. Inner plexiform layer
5. Inner nuclear layer
6. Middle limiting membrane
7. Outer plexiform layer
8. Outer nuclear layer
9. External limiting membrane
10. The layer of rods and cones


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 803,804

questions.text: Which of the following is the normal curvature of lumbar spine?
questions.solution:
Lordosis is normally seen in the lumbar spine.
 
  • The forward curve in the neck (cervical spine) and lower back ( lumbar spine ) known as lordosis is considered normal. 
  • The backword curvature exhibited in the chest (thoracic spine) and hip regions is known as normal kyphosis (sacral spine).
  • A knee malformation known as genu recurvatum causes the knee to bend backwards.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 820

questions.text: Where are Meissner's corpuscles located?
questions.solution:
Meissner's corpuscles are located in papillary dermis.
 
  • The Wagner-Meissner corpuscles, which have a tactile function are primarily found in the papillary dermis of the palms and soles. 
  • It is a rapidly adapting ( phasic receptor ) which responds to changes in texture and slow vibrations. 
  • It is also used for two point discrimination. 




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 64

questions.text: Which type of connective tissue is found in the arrowed area?
questions.solution:
Type of connective tissue present in the reticular dermis is densely irregular. Dense irregular connective tissue is present in the capsules of different glands and organs, such as the testis, the sclera of the eye, the periosteum, and the perichondrium, as well as the adventitia of big blood arteries, muscle, and nerves.


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 151,157

questions.text: What is the proper pairing between the anatomical limits of lymph nodes and lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
P



Reference-:Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no 778

questions.text: Which of the following muscles does not help in the inversion of the foot?
questions.solution:
Peroneus longus causes eversion of the foot, not the inversion of the foot.
 
  • Fibularis (peroneus) longus and fibularis (peroneus) brevis are located in the lateral compartment.
  • Both the foot and ankle's plantar flexor muscles work in tandem to balance the leg on the foot during standing and walking.


Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 1448

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not relate to smell?
questions.solution:
Hypoglossal (XII) nerve is a motor nerve; does not play the role in olfaction and gustation.

The hypoglossal nerve is the motor supply to all the muscles of the tongue ,except palatoglossus.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 644

questions.text: Which of the following bones is not involved in the formation of the wrist?
questions.solution:
• The wrist joint is created by the scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum articulating with the distal end of the radius and the triangular fibrocartilage.
  • Ulna is not engaged in the development of the wrist because the articular disc excludes it from the wrist joint.


Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition Page no 960,964

questions.text: What makes up the ligamentum flavum?
questions.solution:
The ligamentum flavum has a high content of elastin.
 
  • The ligamentum flavum has so much elastin that it is always under tension and may be stretched by 80% without suffering any harm.
  •  This ligament most likely serves to keep the spinal canal continuously smooth, never overstretched in flexion, and never relaxed in extension.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 120

questions.text:
While walking with his eyes closed, a syphilis patient experienced an unbalance and had to elevate his foot and stomp the ground in order to move.
Which tract is affected by the described condition?
questions.solution:
The tract involved is Dorsal column tract.
 
  • Given condition represents a positive Romberg test in the patient of syphilis.
  • The patient is asked to close his eyes. Loss of equilibrium is viewed as a positive test. 
  • The Romberg test is designed to show how posterior column disease affects a person's ability to maintain an upright posture.
  • Since dorsal column is involved and it carries propioception, thus loss of propioception leads to imbalance when visual input is eliminated by closing eyes.
  • Syphilis involves dorsal column of spinal cord leading to - Tabes dorsalis

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 165

questions.text: Where is the Golgi apparatus located in serous acinar cells?
questions.solution:
Golgi apparatus in serous acinar cells is at supranuclear location.

When stained with silver or another metallic salt, the Golgi apparatus is a distinct cytoplasmic area located close to the nucleus.



 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 9,13

questions.text: Where does the left superior intercostal vein drain?
questions.solution:
Brachiocephalic vein.
 
  • The second and third (and occasionally fourth) left posterior intercostal veins are drained by the left superior intercostal vein.
  • In order to open into the left brachiocephalic vein, it ascends obliquely forward across the left portion of the aortic arch, lateral to the left vagus and medial to the left phrenic nerve.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e106

questions.text: What does erythropoietin act on?
questions.solution:
Kidney-derived cytokine erythropoietin stimulates the terminal proliferation and differentiation of Colony Forming Unit (CFU)-Erythroid progenitors.
 
  • Erythropoietin (EPO) increases the development, differentiation, and proliferation of erythroid precursors, increasing erythrocyte numbers while having a negligible impact on megakaryocytes.
  •  CFU-E, pronormoblasts, and basophilic normoblasts are all significantly affected by EPO.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 546,696

questions.text: Which extracellular matrix macromolecule is connected to actin by integrin?
questions.solution:
Integrin connects actin to fibronectin in extracellular matrix.
 
  • Integrins are a large family of transmembrane heterodimeric glycoproteins that enable cells to adhere to elements of the extracellular matrix, such as laminin and fibronectin, functionally and structurally connecting the intracellular cytoskeleton with the external environment.
  • In addition to mediating firm adhesion and transmigration across endothelium at sites of inflammation, integrins on the surface of leukocytes are crucial for platelet aggregation.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition Page no 24

questions.text: According to Weber-Fechner's Law, what is directly proportional to the strength of the perceived stimulus?
questions.solution:
According to Weber-Fechner's Law, strength of stimulus perceived is directly proportional to intensity of stimulus.

In the middle of the 1800s, Weber initially proposed the Weber-Fechner Principle, which states that gradations of stimulus strength are distinguished roughly in proportion to the logarithm of stimulus strength.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 149

questions.text: What does the maximum area in homunculus represent?
questions.solution:
Maximum area in homunculus signifies increased preciseness of movements.
 
  • Each body part's cortical representation is proportional in size to the skill with which it is utilised in fine, voluntary movement, according to the motor homunculus theory.
  • The parts of the cortex that are involved in speech and hand motions are very vast; humans are particularly good at using the pharynx, lips, and tongue to produce words as well as the fingers and opposable thumbs to manipulate the surroundings.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 232

questions.text: Which indicated area in the provided histology section is related to how massage relieves pain?
questions.solution:
The marked area A is substantia gelatinosa.

Massage activates the A-beta fiber, which influences the dorsal gelatinosa neuron and suppresses the small diameter pain fiber (closing the gate at spinal cord level). 


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 150

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to fibers that directly connect to the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum?
questions.solution:
Fibers reaching directly to the Purkinje cell of cerebellum arise from inferior olivary nuclei.
 
  • The inferior olivary nuclei are the sole source of the ascending fibers.
  •  Each one projects to a Purkinje cell's major dendrites, where it intertwines like a climbing plant. The inferior olivary nuclei receive proprioceptive information from everywhere across the body.
  • On the other hand, the mossy fibers deliver direct proprioceptive input to the cerebellar cortex from every area of the body as well as input from the cerebral cortex via the pontine nuclei.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 243

questions.text: Assuming that no proteins were filtered, calculate net filtration with the following data: PGC = 42 mm Hg (Hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries) PiGC= 16 mm Hg (Oncotic pressure of the plasma in glomerular capillaries) PBC = 12 mm Hg (Hydrostatic pressure In Bowman's space) Assume that no proteins were filtered:
questions.solution:
The net filtration pressure is 14mm of Hg.
There are four pressures to consider: two hydrostatic pressures and two oncotic pressure. These are the Starling forces.
Hence, Net Filtration Pressure(NFP)=PGC-(piGC+ PBS)=42-(12+16)=14mmHg.

PGC-Hydrostatic pressure of the glomerulus.
PBS-Hydrostatic pressure In Bowman's space
piGC-Oncotic pressure of the plasma.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 666,667

questions.text: Which hormones fall under the hypothalamus's inhibitory control?
questions.solution:
Both growth hormone and prolactin are under inhibitory control of hypothalamus.
 
  • Growth hormone release is regulated by the hypothalamus, which also secretes somatostatin, an inhibitor of growth hormone release, as well as growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH).
  • The level of growth hormone release will therefore depend on how these hypothalamic elements interact with one another to affect the pituitary.
  • Hence, the growth hormone secretion stimuli may work by boosting hypothalamic GHRH secretion, lowering somatostatin secretion, or both.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page no 908, 917

questions.text: At the start of puberty, which of the following hormones has a permissive effect?
questions.solution:
The permissive effect is a biochemical phenomenon in which the presence of one hormone allows another hormone to exert its full effects on a target cell. For example, thyroid hormones have a permissive relationship with certain reproductive hormones

Leptin has a permissive action at the onset of puberty by increasing GnRH
 
  • Leptin, a hormone that causes satiety and is released by fat cells, may link body weight to puberty: Leptin injections can restore fertility in obese  mice that are infertile due to a lack of leptin production.
  • In young female mice, leptin therapy also causes early puberty.
Clinical Edge- Infertility is seen in female athletes who have very low body fat percentage. As leptin is released from fat cells.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 319

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds might occur naturally during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Third heart sound(S3) may be a normal finding during pregnancy. S3 is heard in hyperdynamic circulation during physiological stresses like pregnancy, exercise.
  • The presence of an S3 sound is generally considered a normal finding in pregnancy and in young adults but is relatively rare in the healthy pregnant state.
Other options: -
  • Fixed split S2 seen in ASD hence pathological.
  • S4 is seen in decreased ventricular compliance like Ischemic heart disease, hence pathological. 
  • Pericardial knock is seen in Constrictive Pericarditis. 
 

Reference:Williams Obstetrics 25th Edition Page no 61

questions.text: Which cell organelle is missing in the area marked by the arrow in the heart muscle
questions.solution:
The region marked by arrow is the perinuclear region which doesnt contain lysosomes in a cardiac muscle fiber. 

Although lacking lysosomes, this perinuclear area is abundant in mitochondria and has  Golgi apparatus, glycogen granules, and lipofuscin granules.


Reference: https://www.kenhub.com/en/library/anatomy/cardiac-tissue

questions.text: The lung's compliance curve is shown below: Which of the following does Curve A represent?
questions.solution:
This curve represents compliance.
 
  • The graph (A)left and up arrows denote higher compliance.
  •  Reduced compliance is shown in the graph(B) on the right and down.
  • Thus, emphysema is the cause (Increased compliance). All of the additional disorders have decreased compliance.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 619

questions.text: Which of the following can rapidly provide energy by resynthesizing ATP for exercising muscles?
questions.solution:
Phosphocreatine is the rapid source of energy for re synthesizing ATP for exercising muscles.
 
  • By providing a rapidly available, high-energy phosphate that may be used to rebuild ATP from ADP, creatine phosphate reduces the rapid depletion of ATP.
  • When the muscle is relaxed and the demands for ATP are not as high, creatine phosphate is produced from ATP and creatine.

Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 108

questions.text: What is likely accumulated in a child with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
The probable biochemical defect is the presence of very long chain fatty acids.
 
  • Those with a rare genetic lack of peroxisomes in all tissues suffer from Zellweger's (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome.
  • Further to showing an all-over loss of peroxisomal activities, they also reveal an accumulation of C, C polyenoic acids in brain tissue.
  • The majority of patients pass away during the first year of birth due to the disease's severe neurological symptoms.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 225.

questions.text: What is the respiratory quotient following a carbohydrate meal?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Quotient (RO) after a heavy carbohydrate meal is 1.

An increase in the respiratory quotient (the ratio of carbon dioxide produced to oxygen consumed), from around 0.8 in the preserved state to close to I, indicates that glucose is the main fuel for oxidation in the majority of tissues.
RQ=CO2 produced/O2 consumed
 
RQ Value Metabolic Fuel Examples
1.0 Carbohydrate metabolism Complete oxidation of glucose (e.g., exercise or carbohydrate-rich diet).
0.7 Fat metabolism Lipid oxidation (e.g., fasting or low-carb diet).
0.8 Protein metabolism Protein catabolism (e.g., starvation).
0.8–0.9 Mixed diet (normal conditions) A combination of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 138.

questions.text: Northern blot detects?
questions.solution:
Northern blot is used for RNA.
Blotting procedures:
  • Southern blot-DNA
  • Northern blot-RNA
  • Western blot-protein
  • Southwestern blot-DNA-binding proteins.
Memorizing Technique: -
South Indian Food- Dosa - DNA
North Indian Food- Roti- RNA 
Western Food- Paratha- Protein 
 
Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 483.

questions.text: Which is a biomarker of alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
In alcoholic hepatitis, AST is typically elevated and often shows a higher level compared to ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase), usually with an AST/ALT ratio greater than 2:1.
This ratio is a hallmark of alcoholic liver disease.
 

While GGT (gamma-glutamyl transferase) and ALP (alkaline phosphatase) can also be elevated in liver disease, AST is the more specific biomarker for alcoholic liver injury.
LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) is less specific and can be elevated in various conditions.


Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 251.

questions.text: What is the method of glucose transfer in the intestine?
questions.solution:
Secondary active transport is the method of transport of glucose in the intestine.

Cells can take up glucose either through facilitated diffusion or, in the kidneys and gut, through a secondary active transport with Na.
GLUT receptors mediate facilitated diffusion.

SGLT 1- Kidney, GIT
SGLT 2- Kidney

 You can remember SGLTs by keeping in mind we have only 1 Gut whereas 2 Kidneys
Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 52

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct in noncompetitive inhibition?
1. Km decreases
2. Vmax decreases
3. No change in Vmax
4. Both Km and Vmax increases
questions.solution:
The maximum reaction velocity (Vmax) decreases because the overall number of functional enzyme molecules is reduced.
In competitive inhibition, Km increases and Vmax remains same.
In noncompetitive inhibition,Km remains same whereas Vmax decreases.

Trick : -
KiVu- Kmax increase, Vmax unchanged- Competitive
KuVr- Kmax unchanged, Vmax reduced- Non competitive


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 77.

choices.text: Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA

questions.text: Which of the following will naturally take place in a type 1 diabetes patient's body when they complain of polyuria?
questions.solution:
In the body of the patient with DM-1 there is Increased conversion of fatty acid to acetyl CoA.
 
  • Reduced insulin levels result in reduced fatty acid synthesis and increased glucagon levels in people with type 1 diabetes.
  • Reduced acetyl CoA carboxylase activity results in decreased malonyl CoA,an allosteric inhibitor of CPT-I, the rate-limiting enzyme of beta-oxidation, as a result of decreasing insulin levels.
  • Hence, unchecked beta-oxidation causes an increase in the conversion of fatty acids to acetyl CoA.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 146.

questions.text:
Which of the following tubes contains sodium fluoride as an anticoagulant?
1. 
2. 
3.
4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Gray vacutainer

Gray vacutainer contains sodium fluoride and is used for glucose estimation because sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis.

* [Extra Edge]: Color Coding of Vacutainers


Online Reference: Gupta S, Kaur H. Inhibition of Glycolysis for Glucose Estimation in Plasma: Recent Guidelines and their Implications. Indian J Clin Biochem. 2014 Apr;29(2):262-4. doi: 10.1007/s12291-013-0405-1. Epub 2013 Nov 22. PMID: 24757316; PMCID: PMC3990791.

questions.text: Determine the pedigree's inheritance pattern.
questions.solution:
The given inheritance pattern is X-linked recessive.
 
  • Only Males are affected - females are carriers as seen in the above pedigree suggesting X-linked recessive inheritance. 
  • A few well-identified clinical disorders like Hemophilia/ Color Blindness have X-linked recessive inheritance.
  • The Y chromosome is not homologous to the X, hence mutant X chromosome genes do not have matching Y chromosome alleles.
  • The male is said to be hemizygous for X-linked mutant genes as a result, and as a result, the male manifests these illnesses. 
  • Females are hemizygous - hence - act as carriers, and do not manifest the disease. 
The following table summarises identification points for various modes of inheritance: 
 




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 640

questions.text: What causes naive T-cell activation?
questions.solution:
While Dendritic cells, Macrophages, and B-lymphocytes - all three are APC(Antigen-presenting cells) - The Naive T-cells get activated predominantly by dendritic cells. They are the most crucial antigen-presenting cells for triggering T-cell responses against protein antigens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 140.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure whereby macrophages engulf various cells as seen in the picture?
questions.solution:
• Emperipolesis is the active engulfment of one cell by another, which remains intact. Seen in Rosai Dorfman disease.
  • In contrast to phagocytosis, where the engulfing cell is killed by the protective action of lysosomal enzymes, it exists momentarily within another cell and with an entire normal structure.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 840.

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to killing caused by antibodies?
questions.solution:
Effector cells that mediate Antibody dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity include NK Cells, monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils,   eosinophils and dendritic cells.
 
Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity is a different process that can result in antibody-mediated cell death (ADCC).
A number of effector cells, primarily NK cells and macrophages, destroy cells that are coated with IgG antibodies by binding to the largest amount of the Fc fragment of IgG, which results in cell destruction without phagocytosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immune privilege site?
questions.solution:
Seminiferous tubule of testis is an immune-privileged site.

Immune-privileged sites
  • Due to the tissues' inability to communicate with the blood and lymph, some antigens are hidden (sequestered) from the immune system.
  • Self-antigens in these tissues consequently do not trigger immunological responses and are generally disregarded by the immune system.
  • Such sites are referred to as immune-privileged sites because it is challenging to elicit immune responses in response to antigens injected into them.
  • Eye lens, CNS, and testis are examples of Immune Privileged sites. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 188.

questions.text: Which of the following can recognize dead material during inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inflammasome

The inflammasome is a protein complex that recognizes products of dead cells and some microbes and induces the secretion of biologically active interleukins.
  • A protein complex called the inflammasome detects the byproducts of dead cells and some bacteria and triggers the release of physiologically active interleukin 1.
  • A sensor protein (NLRP3, a leucine-rich protein), an adaptor, and the enzyme caspase-1, which is changed from an inactive to an active form, make up the inflammasome.
  • The inflammasome has also been implicated in inflammatory reactions to urate crystals (the cause of gout), lipids (in metabolic syndrome and obesity-associated type 2 diabetes), cholesterol crystals (in atherosclerosis), and even amyloid deposits in the brain (in Alzheimer disease).

Fig: The Inflammasome


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 192.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic diarrhea, a normal D-xylose test, and a negative Schilling test. Duodenal biopsies are typical. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical scenario and lab reports, the probable diagnosis is pancreatic insufficiency. The duodenal biopsy is normal and D-xylose is normal but Schilling test is negative that means vitamin B12 is not absorbed that is suggestive of Pancreatic insufficiency or Chronic pancreatitis. 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 302.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about apoptosis is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cell swelling

  • Cell size is reduced, the cytoplasm is dense and eosinophilic, and the organelles, although relatively normal, are more tightly packed.
  • This contrasts with necrosis, in which an early feature is cell swelling, not shrinkage.
* [Extra Edge]: Morphologic features of Apoptotic cell

  • Cell shrinkage- Cell size is reduced, the cytoplasm is dense and eosinophilic, and the organelles although relatively normal, are more tightly packed. This contrasts with necrosis, in which an early feature is cell swelling, not shrinkage.
  • Chromatin condensation- This is the most characteristic feature of apoptosis. The chromatin aggregates peripherally, under the nuclear membrane, into dense masses of various shapes and sizes. The nucleus itself may break up into two or more fragments.
  • Formation of cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies- The apoptotic cell first shows extensive surface membrane blebbing, which is followed by fragmentation of the dead cells into membrane bound apoptotic bodies composed of cytoplasm and tightly packed organelles, with or without nuclear fragments.
  • Phagocytosis of apoptotic cells or cell bodies, usually by macrophages- The apoptotic bodies are rapidly ingested by phagocytes and degraded by the phagocyte’s lysosomal enzymes.
  • In H&E-stained tissue, the apoptotic cell appears as a round or oval mass of intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm with fragments of dense nuclear chromatin.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 43.

questions.text: A trauma patient arrives at the emergency room. There is no time for cross-matching. Which group's Fresh frozen plasma(FFP) can be safely transfused?
questions.solution:
Correct option is (3) AB RhD+. 

Please note, the question is asking about plasma - not RBCs.  O being universal donor is valid for RBCs(since individuals with O blood group do not have any antigens on RBC), but not for Plasma.  Plasma of individuals with O blood group will have antibodies against both A and B.
For plasma transfusion - individual with AB blood group - their plasma will not have any antibodies - hence, can be transfused to anyone



It should be AB Rh+ as both plasmas of AB and Rh won't have antibodies(be it against A/B or against Rh factor)and can be safely transfused to anyone. Individuals with Rh negative blood group can sometime have antibodies against Rh in their plasma.
     
Reference: Bailey and Love short practice of Surgery  Edition 28 th Page no 21
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4469576/

questions.text: Identify the star marked structure in the illustration below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lipofuscin granules
 
  • The marked structure in the given image is the accumulation of lipofuscin granules in perinuclear location. 
  • Lipofuscin, sometimes referred to as lipochrome or "wear-and-tear pigment," is an insoluble pigment.
  • Lipofuscin is composed of polymers of lipids and phospholipids in complex with protein, suggesting that it is derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of intracellular membranes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 64.

choices.text: Inform the infection control board of hospital

questions.text: While collecting blood, an intern spilled it all over the floor. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
• Next step is to put some absorbable material over it so that the blood spill doesn't spread.
  • After that 1% sodium hypochlorite solution is commonly used as a disinfectant to clean up blood spills.
  • It effectively kills pathogens such as bacteria and viruses.

• Before cleaning, ensure to don appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves and possibly a face mask to prevent exposure to bloodborne pathogens.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 145.

questions.text:
The image below shows the immunofluorescence staining pattern from a kidney sample taken from a 35-year-old patient who was experiencing proteinuria.
What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lupus nephritis

The most probable diagnosis is of Lupus nephritis.
 
  • Strong IgA, IgM, and C3 staining may be seen in the picture, although IgG positive staining is lesser.
  • All kinds of glomerulonephritis present in SLE, as well as positive IgA, IgM, C3, and IgG, are frequently observed (lupus nephritis). IgG and C3 positivity is present in PSGN and Goodpasture syndrome; IgM and C3 positivity is seen in FSGS.
  • It is called full house effect. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions exhibit anti-centromere antibodies?
questions.solution:
Anti-centromere antibodies are seen in scleroderma.

The CREST (calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia) variety of the restricted type of systemic sclerosis is frequently characterized by a chronic course and anticentromere antibodies.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 17th edition, Page no 2089.

questions.text: patient came in with an intermittent fever, no weight loss, and no anorexia, but a retroperitoneal tumor. Results from the peripheral smear were normal. The mass is shown in both gross and microscopical form. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Castleman’s disease


*Clinical Features:

  1. B symptoms: fever, weight loss, night sweats, fatigue 

  2. Splenomegaly or Hepatomegaly

  3. Fluid accumulation (edema, anasarca, pleural effusion)

* [Extra Edge]: Castleman disease

  1. Castleman disease (CD) is a rare, nonclonal lymphoproliferative disorder having distinct subtypes depending on its etiology, pathology, and clinical presentation. It can affect lymph nodes of any body region, imitating both benign and malignant malformations, including the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

  2. The hyaline vascular type has an increased number of lymphoid follicles with a broad mantle zone and hypoplastic germinal center. Centrally placed germinal center is surrounded with small lymphocytes arranged in concentric circles, forming an "onion skin-like" structure. The center of these follicles is penetrated by hyalinized capillaries resembling a "lollipop" (also known as the lollipop sign).

  • Histopathologic screening of lymph nodes is done to assess a single node involvement (suggestive of UCD) or a multimode involvement (suggesting MCD) after excluding other infectious, malignant, and autoimmune disorders that exhibit their characteristic features in the lymph nodes. In addition, their characteristic lymph node features are also noted.

  • The lymph node size must be enlarged.

  • IL-6 has proven to be a specific biomarker for this disease, contributing to its pathogenesis, symptomatology, and histopathology. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 257.
Online Reference: Ehsan N, Zahra F. Castleman Disease. [Updated 2023 Apr 27]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK576394/

questions.text: How can a mediastinal mass be distinguished from a thymoma or an ALL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cytokeratin

Cytokeratin is an epithelial cell marker, present in thymoma and absent in lymphoma.
 
  • Since solid tumor cells frequently include intermediate filaments distinctive of their cell of origin, antibodies specific to intermediate filaments have shown to be of great utility in such circumstances.
  • An epithelial origin (carcinoma) is indicated by the presence of cytokeratins, which can be detected by immunohistochemistry, whereas desmin is only present in tumors that have muscle cell origins.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 632.

questions.text: Which of the following are not side effects of salbutamol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypoglycemia
 
  • Hypoglycemia is not a side effect of Salbutamol.
  • Salbutamol, a beta-2 agonist, enhances glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis while also raising plasma glucose levels.
  • They also boost insulin release while lowering blood sugar levels. However, the first consequence, which causes hyperglycemia, predominates

Trick to memorise side effects of salbutamol: -
Tremor
Tachycardia
Tolerance
T-wave changes(Hypokalemia)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: What determines a drug's loading dose?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) Volume of distribution

Loading dose= Volume of distribution* plasma concentration
Loading Dose is a single or few quickly repeated doses given in the beginning to attain target concentration rapidly.
 
Loading dose depends on the volume of distribution and not on CL or t½.

Loading Dose immediately raises the concentration of the medication in plasma to the desired concentration and given when the delay to reach steady state is significant, as it is for medicines having extended half-lives.

The proportionality factor that links the overall amount of drug in the body to the concentration is the volume of distribution.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 41.

choices.text: Drug is not extensively distributed in organs and tissues

questions.text: What does a low apparent volume of distribution indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 4) Drug is not extensively distributed in organs and tissues.
 
  • The drug is more concentrated in the vascular compartment and less so in the organs and tissues, according to the low apparent volume of distribution.
  • Poor lipid solubility or strong plasma protein binding of the medication can cause low distribution volume. 

* Factors determining Volume of Distribution: -

1. Lipid solubility- directly proportional 
2. Fat content - directly proportional 
3. Plasma Protein Binding- inversely proportional 
 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 23, 24.

questions.text:
Diamox, a noncompetitive antagonist of carbonic anhydrase, is prescribed for glaucoma. What causes the effect?
1. Increase in Km and Vmax
2. Decrease in Km
3. Decrease in Vmax
4. No change in Vmax
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) due to a decrease in Vmax.

A noncompetitive antagonist of carbonic anhydrase Diamox (acetazolamide) is given for glaucoma. 

* Non competitive antagonism:

  • Drug binds to a difficult allosteric site altering the receptor so unable to combine with agonist.  

  • Efficacy and Vmax decreases.

  • Dose, potency and Km does not change.

Trick : -
KiVu- Kmax increase, Vmax unchanged- Competitive
KuVr- Kmax unchanged, Vmax reduced- Non competitive
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 47.

questions.text: What medication is used to prevent acute mountain sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acetazolamide

Acetazolamide can provide symptomatic relief in patients with high-altitude illness or mountain sickness in which there is Weakness, dizziness, insomnia, headache, and nausea in mountain travelers who rapidly ascend above 3000 meters.
 
  • Acetazolamide can improve breathing and lessen the effects of mountain sickness by reducing CSF production and by lowering the pH of the CSF and brain.
  • Furthermore helpful in the management of sleep apnea is this modest metabolic central and CSF acidosis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 633.

questions.text: Which of the following medications kills gametes of all Plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Primaquine

Primaquine is gametocidal for all species of Plasmodium.
 
  • Primaquine is effective against all human malaria parasites in their hepatic stages.
  • It is the sole treatment on the market that is effective against P vivax and P. ovale's dormant hypnozoite stages.
  • Moreover, the medication shows modest efficacy against parasites in the erythrocytic stage and is gametocidal against all four human malaria species.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: Which drug should be used as the least-resort treatment for a male with insulin-dependent diabetes who has macular edema and develops glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Prostaglandin analogue
 
  • Prostaglandin analogues can potentially worsen diabetic macular edema and is generally not recommended in patients with diabetic retinopathy due to its potential effects on retinal fluid dynamics.
  • Therefore, it would be considered the least appropriate choice for managing glaucoma in this context. Common side effect of prostaglandin analogue is Cystoid Macular edema.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: In a pregnant female taking lithium - what needs to be checked for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cardiac anomaly
 
  • Lithium is categorized as having a D risk level.
  • Cardiac anomalies should be checked in the newborn if lithium is given to a pregnant female. 
  • Cardiac Malformations (especially Ebstein Anomaly) are commonly associated with using Lithium in pregnancy.
* [Extra Edge]: Lithium


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 476.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects increases when valproate is used with carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hepatotoxicity

The risk of hepatotoxicity increases if carbamazepine is used along with valproate.
  • By way of CYP450 enzymes, valproate is converted into the hepatotoxic minor metabolite 2-propyl-4-pentenoic acid (4-ene-VPA).
  • The microsomal enzymes can be induced, and the production of this metabolite increased by enzyme inducers like carbamazepine, phenytoin, and phenobarbital.
Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 416.

questions.text: Which of the given options is an antitubercular medicine that causes ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ethambutol

Ethambutol can cause ophthalmic toxicity in the form of optic neuritis and red green colorblindness.

* Ethambutol:
  • Retrobulbar neuritis, which causes a loss of visual acuity and red-green colorblindness, is the most frequent major adverse effect.
  • When dosages of 25 mg/kg/d are sustained for several months, this dose-related adverse effect is more likely to develop.
  • Specialists advise baseline and recurring assessments of color perception and visual acuity, paying particular attention to those who are taking higher doses or who have other conditions.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 820.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs do not increase bleeding when given to a patient on warfarin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Carbamazepine
 
  • Inducers of CYP2C9 like carbamazepine, increase metabolism of warfarin and hence decrease plasma concentration and increases risk of thrombosis.
  • Warfarin's ability to break down in the body can be inhibited by CYP2C9 inhibitors such fluoxetine, isoniazid, amiodarone, cimetidine, tolcapone, and cotrimoxazole, which can raise warfarin levels in the blood and cause bleeding symptoms

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 442.

questions.text: Where does the primary action of nitrates in angina patients occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Decreases Preload

Sublingual administration of nitrates reduces O2 demand primarily by preload reduction rather than coronary artery vasodilation.
* Antianginal Effects of Organic Nitrates depends on Following mechanisms:
  • Reduced cardiac O2 demand- The major determinants of myocardial O2 consumption are left ventricular wall tension, heart rate, and myocardial contractility. Ventricular wall tension is affected by preload and afterload.
  • Increase in the delivery of O2 to ischemic regions of myocardium- When considering the effect of vasodilators in the ischemic heart, it is important to realize that myocardial ischemia itself is a powerful stimulus to coronary vasodilation and part of an autoregulatory mechanism.
* Experimental Evidence:
  • when GTN is injected directly into the coronary circulation of patients with CAD, anginal attacks (induced by electrical pacing) are not aborted even when coronary blood flow is increased.
  • In contrast, sublingual administration of GTN does relieve anginal pain in the same patients, indicating that the major antianginal effect of nitro vasodilators is mediated by preload reduction rather than coronary artery dilation.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: What purpose does the technique shown in the image serve?
questions.solution:
The given diagram is known as the hybridoma technique for the development of monoclonal antibodies.

A mouse is given an antigen to which B cells in the spleen make antibodies.
These lymphocyte cells (seen as spleen cells in the diagram) are gathered and combined with myeloma cells to form hybridomas.
These hybridomas then divide and produce monoclonal antibodies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 150.

questions.text: Store a medicine in a cool place refers to keeping it at what temperature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 8°–15°

Store a drug in a cool place refers to storing at the temperature of 8-15°C.

Any temperature below 8 °C, typically between 2 and 8 °C, is considered Cold.

Cool: a temperature range of 8 to 25 °C. 
Room temperature: Average temperature in a workspace.
Warm: Between 30 and 40 °C 
Excessively hot: Any temperature over 40 °C 

Online Reference: Khuluza F, Chiumia FK, Nyirongo HM, Kateka C, Hosea RA, Mkwate W. Temperature variations in pharmaceutical storage facilities and knowledge, attitudes, and practices of personnel on proper storage conditions for medicines in southern Malawi. Front Public Health. 2023 Sep 22;11:1209903. doi: 10.3389/fpubh.2023.1209903. PMID: 37808988; PMCID: PMC10556513.

choices.text: Stop treatment and follow-up with 6 monthly EEG

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was taking antiepileptic medication to treat episodes of epilepsy while she slept. After six months without a seizure, her NCCT and EEG were both normal. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Continue for 2 years

Drug is slowly tapered off after Continuing for 2 years.

* [Extra Edge]: Withdrawal of Antiepileptic drugs - 
  • Seizure free period of 2 years 
  • Normal CNS examination 
  • Normal EEG and normal MRI
  • Single seizure type
  • No F/H/O seizure
Online Reference:
Laue-Gizzi H. Discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs in adults with epilepsy. Aust Prescr. 2021 Apr;44(2):53-56. doi: 10.18773/austprescr.2021.005. Epub 2021 Apr 1. PMID: 33911333; PMCID: PMC8075746.

questions.text:
A patient is being treated with indinavir, zidovudine, lamivudine, and ketoconazole. Which drug is responsible for his development of central obesity,
nephrolithiasis, hyperlipidemia, and breast hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Indinavir 

Protease inhibitors like indinavir can cause nephrolithiasis.
 
  • Protease inhibitors frequently cause gynecomastia/breast enlargement, dyslipidemia, and obesity.
  • Gynecomastia and breast enlargement are possible adverse effects of Ketoconazole, although none of the others are observed. Zidovudine and stavudine, two NRTIs, produce lipodystrophy and not obesity.

ART Side effects- 

Drug Class Common Drugs Most Common Side Effects
NRTIs - Abacavir- Tenofovir- Lamivudine - Lactic acidosis- Renal toxicity (Tenofovir)- Hypersensitivity (Abacavir)
NNRTIs - Efavirenz - Rash- CNS effects (Efavirenz)- Hepatotoxicity
PIs - Atazanavir- Darunavir - Hyperlipidemia- GI upset- Fat redistribution
Integrase Inhibitors - Dolutegravir - GI upset- Insomnia
Entry Inhibitors - Maraviroc - Hepatotoxicity- Muscle/joint pain
Pharmacokinetic Enhancers - Ritonavir- Cobicistat - GI upset- Liver enzyme elevation

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 865.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about T3 and T4 acting on THR(Thyroid hormone receptor) is correct?
questions.solution:
T3 T4 acts on transcription factor.
 
  • Nuclear hormone receptors in humans belong to a superfamily of 48 receptors that react to a wide range of ligands.
  • The transcription factors known as receptor proteins are able to influence the expression of genes regulating many physiological functions, including reproduction, development, and metabolism.
  • Receptors for circulating steroid hormones like androgens, oestrogens, glucocorticoids, thyroid hormone, and vitamin D are well-known members of the family.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 55

questions.text: In which of the following conditions should morphine not be given to a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Biliary colic
 
  • Morphine can cause contraction of sphincter of Oddi and biliary spasm; hence it can worsen pain of biliary colic and is not used for the same.
  • The opioids can cause biliary colic by tightening the biliary smooth muscle and
  • As a result of the sphincter of Oddi constricting, biliary and pancreatic secretions may reflux, and plasma amylase and lipase levels may rise.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 500.

choices.text: Inhibition of sterol of the cell wall
Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis

questions.text: Dapsone is employed as an immunomodulator, antifungal, and antibacterial. What process underlies each of these actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis

Dapsone Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis.
 
  • Dapsone is a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase (folP1/P2) in the folate pathway and a structural analogue of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA).
  • Dapsone's impact on this evolutionarily conserved route also explains why it has antibacterial, anti-protozoal, and antifungal properties.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 831.

questions.text: Which is the schedule of drugs to be sold only on prescription?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Schedule H

Schedule H can only be sold after prescription.
 
  • Schedule H is a group of prescription pharmaceuticals that are legal in India and are listed as an appendix to the 1945 Drugs and Cosmetics Rules.
  • These are medications that require a prescription from a licensed physician in order to be acquired over-the-counter.
* Other Important Schedules: -

Schedule X- narcotics and psychotropic drugs 
Schedule G- Includes hormonal medications
 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 7.

questions.text: When should we switch to heparin in a pregnant woman with rheumatic heart disease who has a prosthetic valve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 36 weeks.

Warfarin should be held after 36 weeks' gestation (during 37th week) and replaced with LMWH or unfractionated heparin.
 
  • Before giving birth, anticoagulation should be avoided because warfarin, which crosses the placenta, raises the risk of fetal intraventricular hemorrhage, and therapeutic anticoagulation increases the risk for hemorrhagic complications with regional anesthetic.
  • The purpose of conversion to UFH has less to do with any risk of maternal bleeding at the time of Delivery, but rather with neuraxial blockade complicated by an epidural or spinal hematoma.
  • Administration of warfarin during pregnancy causes birth defects and abortion especially in first trimester.  Fetal or neonatal hemorrhage and intrauterine death may occur, even when maternal INR values are within the therapeutic range. Vitamin K antagonists should not be used during pregnancy, but heparin or LMWH can be used safely.
  • Anticoagulation algorithm is pregnancy- 1st trimester LMWH, 2nd trimester upto 36 weeks warfarin, after 36 weeks LMWH or Heparin.
Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page No 985.

questions.text: What is being tested in the phase 1 trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Safety.

Phase I trials are done mainly for testing Human pharmacology and safety> Maximum tolerable dose> Pharmacokinetic parameters.
So answer varies depending upon the options provided. The correct answer would be safety.

Therapeutic Exploration and Dose Ranging is Main focus of Phase 2 Clinical trial.
 
  • The human pharmacokinetic parameters of the drug are measured for the first time.
  • Subjects (mostly healthy volunteers, sometimes patients) are exposed to the drug one by one, starting with the lowest estimated dose and increasing stepwise to achieve the effective dose.
  • An attempt is made to determine the dose range that may be used in further studies. The emphasis is on safety, tolerability, and to detect any potentially dangerous effects.
  • No blinding is done: the study is open label.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page No 90.

questions.text: What is the mechanism through which acetylcholine lowers heart rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Delayed diastolic depolarization

Acetylcholine lowers heart rate primarily through preventing diastolic depolarization, or the spontaneous depolarization of cells in the SA node.
  • Acetylcholine hyperpolarizes the SA nodal cells and decreases their rate of diastolic depolarization. As a result, rate of impulse generation is reduced bradycardia, or even cardiac arrest may occur.
  • At the A-V node and His-Purkinje fibers refractory period (RP) is increased and conduction is slowed: P-R interval increases and partial to complete A-V block may be produced.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text: Which mechanism does nitroprusside's active metabolite use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Guanyl cyclase

Sodium nitroprusside active metabolite is Nitric oxide.
Nitric oxide activates guanylyl cyclase and raises levels of cyclic GMP. Myosin light chain phosphorylase, which is dephosphorylated by protein kinase G when cyclic GMP is activated, relaxes the smooth muscles in blood vessels.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 544.

questions.text: A pediatrician attended an infant who had an unconjugated serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. What medications could the mother have taken during the third trimester?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cotrimoxazole
 
  • Cotrimoxazole if given near term may cause neonatal hemolysis and methemoglobinemia.
  • Cotrimoxazole is not clearly proven to be hazardous during pregnancy, especially if the dosage is decreased early on to diminish the minor risk of fetal hemolysis and methemoglobinemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 758.

questions.text: Which of the following dose reductions is not required in renal failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Doxycycline 
 
  • Doxycycline is safe in renal failure dose reduction is not required.
  • In contrast to tigecycline, which is primarily excreted intact along with a minor quantity of glucuronidated metabolites, and minocycline, which is significantly processed by the liver prior to excretion, doxycycline is largely excreted unchanged in both the bile and urine.
  • The dosages of these drugs don't need to be adjusted for people with renal failure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 79.

questions.text: Verapamil was administered to a patient who was taking metoprolol for hypertension. What will this lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bradycardia with AV block 
 
  • Among the following bradycardia with AV block are likely to happen with the above combination therapy.
  • Verapamil and metoprolol (beta-blocker) show drug interaction and result in precipitation of bradycardia and AV block since both have inhibitory action on AV node and oppose positive inotropic action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text:
A post-renal transplant patient complains of diarrhea, after three months. Stool microscopy showed organisms that were Kinyoun stain positive and measuring 2 to 6 microns.
What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
During the first three to six months following transplantation, opportunistic infections are particularly prevalent in post-transplant patients.
 
Due to extensive antibiotic use, Clostridium difficile is typically discovered within one month following transplantation.
 
A positive Kinyon stain (Modified acid fast) rule eliminates Balantidium. Size between 2 and 6 micrometers is indicative of Cryptosporidium hominis (previously parvum). Cystoisospora size 23-36 micrometers. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 98.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room with a history of passing tiny amounts of mucus-filled, frequent, thin stools, a sense of heat, lower abdominal pain, and leukocytes in the stool. Which of the following organisms is most likely the cause?
questions.solution:
Entamoeba is the most likely cause.
 
As a chronic condition, amoebiasis (caused by Entamoeba) can result in sporadic stomach pain and mucoid, bloody diarrhea.
 
WBCs can be seen in the feces in amoebiasis. Around 10% to 30% of patients with amoebiasis will experience fever. All illnesses—aside from amoebiasis—cause watery, non-bloody diarrhea.

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 18.

choices.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid
Carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, and methylene blue

questions.text:
A patient develops a thick, gray coating on their tonsils and throat, which is followed by fever, chills, and swollen glands the next week.
Microscopic examination of a nasopharyngeal or pharyngeal swab revealed gram-positive organisms with a special stain. What are the constituents of the stain?
questions.solution:
It is Albert stain and its constituents are Toluidine blue, malachite green, Glacial acetic acid
 
  • The clinical characteristics indicated are suggestive of diphtheria.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria e's metachromatic granules are stained with Albert Stain.
  • Malachite green and toluidine blue O are the two stains that make up the Albert stain.
  • Volutin granules, the acidic portion of the cell, are stained by toluidine blue O, and the cytoplasm is stained by malachite green.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 14.

questions.text: What stimulates IFN-beta?
questions.solution:
IFN-beta is stimulated by viral infection.

After being stimulated by viruses or polynucleotides, fibroblast and epithelial cells synthesize beta interferon (IFN-B), formerly known as fibroblast interferon. It is glycoprotein in nature. 
Types of Interferons: •IFN alpha - Leukocyte Interferon, has antiviral activity. •IFN beta - Produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells, has antiviral activity. •IFN gamma - Produced by T- lymphocytes, has immunomodulatory and anti- proliferative functions.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 352.

questions.text:
A patient who is suffering from diarrhea  had kidney transplantation in the past. The figure provided information on the worms' motility. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding the organism?

a. Monoecious and the organism is related with parthenogenesis
b. Transmitted by intake of contaminated food and water
c. Loffler’s pneumonia is not caused by the same organism
d. Body gets this infection through filariform larvae
questions.solution:
Body gets this infection through filariform larvae.
 
  • Strongyloides stercoralis rhabditiform larvae are seen in the video. S. stercoralis is a parthenogenetic organism that is dioecious.
  • Infectious form is filariform larva (Eggs give rise to larvae and develop into filariform larvae) that penetrate the skin.
  • Loffler's pneumonia is caused by hookworms and Ascaris.
Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 181.

questions.text: Which is the cause of bacterial meningitis in a one-year-old child?
questions.solution:
The causative agent of bacterial meningitis in a 1-year child is Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus)

In Neonates, acute bacterial meningitis is caused by :-
  • Group B Streptococcus (most common)
  • E. Coli
  • Listeria
In childhood, adults and elderly,the organisms causing acute bacterial meningitis are:- 
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides (meningococcus)
  • H. Influenza B
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 335.

questions.text: At a party, 200 people showed up, and some of them had diarrhea the next day. They consumed potato salad, hamburgers, oysters, and ice cream. 40 ill from 50 who consumed oyster 50 ill from 135 who consumed hamburger 60 ill from 140 who consumed salad 49 ill from 115 who consumed ice cream What is the most likely cause of this?What is the most likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
Vibrio parahaemolyticus is the most likely causative agent.
 
  • It is typically detected in late summer in raw oyster from polluted oyster beds. It has a minor gastroenteritis connection. Sushi and raw seafood also contain it.
  • Infected eggs are the main method of transmission for Salmonella enteritidis. Undercooked egg consumption is a significant risk factor. Between 12 to 72 hours of eating contaminated food, it might induce diarrhea.
  • Acute diarrhea, terminal ileitis, mesenteric lymphadenitis, and pseudo-appendicitis are all symptoms of Yersinia enterocolitica. Pork, milk, water, and tofu contamination are all linked to human yersiniosis.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 318.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in "aggravated penetrative sexual assault" under the POCSO Act 2012?
questions.solution:
Threatening is not included under Aggravated penetrative sexual assault under POCSO act 2012.

According to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offenses (POCSO) Act, a crime is considered to be "Aggravated" when it is done by someone who has the authority over or is in a position of trust over a child, such as a member of the security forces, a police officer, a public employee, etc.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: Within how much time should a patient’s records on demand be provided in case of professional misconduct?
questions.solution:
Whenever professional misconduct is suspected, patient records should be made available upon request within 72 hours.
 
  • Professional misconduct is defined as any behavior by a doctor that could be considered shameful or disgraceful.
  • In the event of professional misconduct, the healthcare provider must produce the indoor patient's medical records upon request within 72 hours if they have been kept for three years.
  • Medical records should be provided to patients or legal authorities on request within 72 hours and planning is being made this period to 5 days. Maintain records (should be fully digitized) of indoor patients for 3 years.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 327.

questions.text: What is bullet fingerprinting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3. Secondary markings

Bullet fingerprinting is the presence of secondary markings on the bullet, useful to identify one specific gun to the exclusion of all others.
 
  • The bullet's primary and secondary markings aid in identifying the weapon.
  • When compared to markings on a bullet that was test-fired from the suspected gun, secondary marks that are caused by an elevation or depression on the inner surface of the barrel of the gun will tell specifically about the particular gun that has been used.
  • Primary markings on the surface of the bullet provide information about the "make" or type of the gun used.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem finding in the image shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Suggillation
 
  • The image is suggestive of post-mortem hypostasis, which is also known as suggillation.
  • Postmortem hypostasis is the bluish-purple or purplish red coloring (caused by deoxyhemoglobin) that develops in the dependent parts of the body after death in the dermis's most superficial layers, Also known as livor mortis, suggillation, vibices, postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, and darkening of death.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 155.

questions.text:
A woman's body was discovered in her bedroom. The door to the room was not closed. 350 mg/dL of alcohol in the blood was shown along with images of the face,
open neck, and viscera. A picture was provided showing cyanosed lips and probable six-penny bruises on the neck. Soft tissue ecchymosis was visible in the
dissected neck. What is the most likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
Presence of bruises in the neck,cyanosed lip and Dissected neck showing soft tissue ecchymosis is highly suggestive of throttling.
 
  • Throttling, also known as manual strangulation:
  • Throttling is the asphyxia that results from the compression of the neck by human hands. Carotid artery blockage is the cause of death. Occlusion of the airway has a small impact.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 353.

questions.text: Within how many days a vaginal swab can be taken from a rape victim?
questions.solution:
Vaginal swab can be taken from a rape victim within 4 days.
 
  • Vaginal examination is done using a sterile speculum.
  • Examining the cervix, vaginal walls, and vault for redness, bruising, or tears. The case history, the amount of time that has passed since the assault and the examination, the type of assault, and whether or not she has showered or washed herself since the assault all influence the type of swabs and samples that are taken.
  • The likelihood of obtaining evidence is considerably diminished after 72 hours (3 days),but can be taken up to 96 hours (4 days).
  • After 96 hours, evidence from the outside of the body and from objects like clothing can be gathered.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 365.

questions.text: What is the duration of the measles isolation period?
questions.solution:
Period of isolation for measles is from onset of catarrhal symptoms to 7 days after onset of rash.
Individuals diagnosed with measles should be isolated during this period to prevent the spread of the virus, especially to those who are unvaccinated or have weakened immune systems.
 
The period of communicability of measles is 3 days before and 3 days after the appearance of rash.

questions.text: Which other disease also uses droplets as a means of transmission and requires isolation, like TB?
questions.solution:
Pertussis has  droplet mode of transmission and isolation is done for pertussis.
  • Whooping cough (pertussis) is spread mainly by droplet infection and direct contact.
  • The role of fomites in the spread of the infection appears to be very small, unless they are freshly contaminated.
  • When an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks, tiny droplets containing the bacteria can be released into the air. People nearby can inhale these droplets and become infected.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 182.

questions.text: 40 to 50 instances are reported by a health clinic per week in the neighbourhood. There are typically 48 cases this week. This kind of event is known as:
questions.solution:
A healthy center reports 40 to 50 cases in a week in the community. This week there are 48 cases normally. This kind of occurrence is called endemic, as there is constant presence of a disease in the defined geographical area.
 
  • Endemic refers to the constant presence of a disease or infectious agent within a given geographic area or population group, without importation from outside; may also refer to the “usual” or expected frequency of the disease within such an area or population group, that is, more than 2 Standard Deviations. 
  • The word sporadic means scattered about. The cases occur irregularly, haphazardly from time to time, and generally infrequently (100).
  • Epidemic: The occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness, specific health related behaviour, or other health-related events clearly in excess of normal expectancy. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 101.

questions.text: Which test is used to recognise a frozen vaccine?
questions.solution:
The “shake test” is designed to detect freeze damage in aluminum-based, adsorbed, freeze sensitive vaccines such as
  • DTP
  • DT
  • Td
  • TT
  • typhoid 
  • hepatitis B.
These vaccines must never be frozen as this reduces their immunogenicity.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 123.

questions.text: Except for____________,all of the following are associated with the image:
questions.solution:
This is called Box and Whisker plot.
  • It is a graphical representation of numerical data based on five-figure summary-minimum, 25th percentile, median (50th percentile), 75th percentile and maximum values.
  • The whisker represents the range of the data, while the box represents the interquartile range. That is from 25% to 75% of values (first to third quartile).
  • The median or second quartile is represented by a partition in the box. When most of observations are concentrated on lower end of scale, it is skewed right (positive) or vice versa. In the given image, most of observations are concentrated on higher end of scale, so it is positively skewed or skewed right.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 7.

questions.text: Select the correct response when two screening tests are taken in series:
questions.solution:
• When 2 screening tests are done in series, there is increased specificity and decreased sensitivity. In contrast to doing either test alone, there is a net decrease in sensitivity when two sequential tests are utilised, but a net gain in specificity when those who test positive by the first test are brought in for the second test.
 
  • When two tests are run simultaneously, there is a net increase in sensitivity but a net decrease in specificity as compared to running either test separately. When 2 screening tests are done in parallel, there is decreased specificity and increased sensitivity

Reference: Medical Biostatistics, 3rd edition, Page no 56.

questions.text:
In a clinical trial, a patient group's blood pressure was assessed both before and after the intervention.
Which of the following tests would be appropriate for a significance test?
questions.solution:
• Paired t-test compares study subjects at 2 different times (paired observations of the same subject) on parametric data. 
     
  • Unpaired t-test (aka Student's test) compares two different subjects.
  • The paired t-test reduces inter-subject variability (because it makes comparisons between the same subject), and thus is theoretically more powerful than the unpaired t-test .

In the question, blood pressure was measured in a group of patients before and after treatment, Paired t-test will be suitable as a test of significance.


Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 34.

questions.text:
Which of the following tests would be appropriate as a test of significance in a clinical trial if blood pressure was assessed between
two independent groups after treatment?
questions.solution:
Research volunteers at two different times are compared on parametric data using a paired t-test (paired observations of the same subject).
A t-test that contrasts two unrelated subjects is known as a student's test.

Answer : Unpaired t-test is a good statistical test since blood pressure was measured after treatment in the question between two independent groups.

Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 34.

questions.solution:
The given image is of multibacillary adult blister pack, which is used in multibacillary leprosy.

questions.text: All vaccines are new or recently approved except which among the following:
questions.solution:
Rotavirus, dengue and malaria vaccine are newly introduced vaccine.

  • The dengue vaccine is known as Dengvaxia (CYD-TdV).It is a live recombinant vaccine as a 3-dose series on a 0/6/12 months schedule in Phase-II clinical studies. It has been registered for use in individuals 9-45 years of age living in endemic areas.
  • The RTS,S malaria vaccine, also known as Mosquirix, was developed by GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) in partnership with the PATH Malaria Vaccine Initiative and is designed to target the Plasmodium falciparum parasite that causes malaria, which is spread by anopheles mosquitoes.

questions.text:
The patient had severe transverse myelitis along with recurrent optic neuritis in both eyes. Right eye visual acuity is 6/60, and left eye visual acuity is 6/18.
Steroids had a 50% response rate in the patient. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
History of recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis and significantly diminished visual acuity in both eye along with responsiveness to steroids suggest the diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica.

Neuromyelitis optica is an aggressive inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of ON and myelitis.
