choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A CKD patient complains of vomiting. His ABG reports are as follows: pH = 7.40, pCO2 = 40, HCO3 = 23, Na = 145, chloride = 100. The findings point to:
questions.solution:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

The clinical history is crucial in this case even though the ABG appears to be entirely normal.
  • Patients with CKD typically exhibit significant ion gap metabolic acidosis. In light of it, the patient has started to vomit (which is the state of alkalosis). The ABG in this condition has returned to normal due to both opposing illnesses.
  • The patient therefore has severe anion gap metabolic acidosis together with metabolic alkalosis.

The likely diagnosis is high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) alongside metabolic alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:'
  • Step 1:The pH of 7.4 is within the normal range.  
  • Step 2: The plasma bicarbonate level is 23 mEq/L, which is also normal. At this point, we can exclude options A and C, as this clinical situation does not indicate a straightforward acid-base disorder.  
  • Step 3: Calculating the anion gap:  

Anion gap = [Na+] - ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])  
= 145 - (100 + 23)  
= 22 mEq/L  

A high anion gap confirms the presence of an acid-base disorder, ruling out option A. A high anion gap suggests metabolic acidosis. However, the normal bicarbonate levels indicate that metabolic alkalosis is also present in this patient.

This can be further validated by calculating the delta gap:  
 
  • Delta gap = (AAG - HCO3-)  
  • In this case, Delta gap = (22 - 10) - (24 - 23) = 11 mEq/L.  
  • A delta gap of +6 suggests that metabolic alkalosis exists alongside HAGMA.
  • If the delta gap is significantly positive (> +6), it indicates metabolic alkalosis due to a greater rise in the anion gap compared to the fall in bicarbonate. Conversely, if the delta gap is significantly negative (<6), hyperchloremic acidosis is typically present, as the rise in the anion gap is less than the fall in bicarbonate.

Alternatively, we can use the delta ratio:  
  • Delta ratio = Increase in Anion Gap / Decrease in HCO3-.  
  • This ratio is useful when assessing high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) to determine if it is a 'pure' HAGMA or if there is coexisting normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) or metabolic alkalosis.  

Delta ratio values:  

1-2 indicates HAGMA,  
1 indicates NAGMA + HAGMA,  
2 indicates HAGMA + metabolic alkalosis.  

In this case, the delta ratio is 12/1 = 12. Thus, the acid-base disorder in this scenario is HAGMA with metabolic alkalosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: The following causes death from smoke inhalation:
questions.solution:
he correct answer is 4. All of the above.

Death from smoke inhalation can occur due to multiple mechanisms, including:

  1. Hypoxemia: Reduced oxygen availability in the blood due to the presence of smoke and toxic gases.
  2. Anemic hypoxia: Carbon monoxide in smoke can bind to hemoglobin more effectively than oxygen, reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.
  3. Ischemic hypoxia: Inflammation and damage to lung tissue can impair blood flow and oxygen delivery to tissues.

All of these factors can contribute to the lethal effects of smoke inhalation.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 699.

choices.text: Observe for a change in colour of the urine
Stop BT and wait for patient to get normal and start

questions.text:
The patient has a history of iron overload that has been previously treated with chelating drugs and is a known case of thalassemia major.
She has a background of cardiac arrhythmia as well. She has now come for BT. The patient complained of back pain during BT and appeared very apprehensive.
What is the next treatment?
questions.solution:
During blood transfusion, whenever an adverse reaction is suspected, the transfusion should be stopped and reported to the blood bank for investigation.

Adverse reactions to transfused blood components can occur despite multiple tests, inspections, and checks. Fortunately, the most common reactions are not life threatening, although serious reactions can present with mild symptoms and signs. Some reactions can be reduced or prevented by modified blood components. 
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 888-896.

questions.text: It is uncommon to have relative bradycardia in:
questions.solution:
• Relative bradycardia ( also known as Faget's sign) is uncommon in Staphylococcus infection as compared to given options.
 
  • Typhoid fever, brucellosis, leptospirosis, various drug-induced fevers, and factitious fever all exhibit temperature-pulse dissociation (relative bradycardia).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 944.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful in monitoring cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Central venous catheter alone is not useful for measuring cardiac output.
 
  • Cardiac output is measured by the Fick method or the thermodilution technique.
  • The Fick method uses oxygen as the indicator substance and is based on the principle that the amount of a substance taken up or released by an organ (oxygen consumption) is equal to the product of its blood flow (cardiac output) and the difference in the concentration of the substance in the arterial and venous circulation (arterial-venous oxygen difference).
  • Cardiac output can also be determined with a pulmonary artery catheter and echocardiography. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1861.

questions.text: What is the best KDIGO criteria marker for distinguishing renal from pre-renal acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Urine Na  x serum creatinine /Serum Na x  Urine creatinine is the best marker in KDIGO criteria to differentiate renal from pre-renal acute kidney injury. This is the formula for fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa).

In AKI, there is abrupt loss of kidney function, resulting in retention of urea and other nitrogenous waste products and dysregulation of extracellular volume and electrolytes.

The term AKI has largely replaced acute renal failure (ARF).


Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303, 2305.

questions.text: What recommendations will you provide a cardiac tamponade patient while testing his blood pressure?
questions.solution:
While measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, the patient should breath normally.

Moderate to severe cardiac tamponade, and occasionally constrictive pericarditis, induce hemodynamic changes that enhance the inspiratory fall in systolic blood pressure. This exaggerated drop in systemic blood pressure during inspiration is termed pulsus paradoxus.

Since the depth of respiration influences the severity of pulsus,  patient should not be instructed to change his/her breathing pattern during this evaluation.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 375.

choices.text: Give loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel

questions.text:
A 60 years old female patient has left sided weakness since 1 hour and left sided face weakness with BP, 160/100 mm Hg.
What is the best next step if the CT scan is normal?
questions.solution:
The first step in such patients is NCCT head to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

As CT head is normal in the question, it is suggestive of non-hemorrhagic stroke and Window period for thrombolysis is <4.5 hour so this patient can be considered for thrombolysis with Alteplase/Tenecteplase.
Thrombolytic agent, recombinant t-PA can be use between 3-4.5 hours after the onset of stroke.

The preferred drug is alteplase and it's dose is 0.9 mg/kg. 

Management of Acute Stroke:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3336, 3337.

questions.text: ECG is conducted after the patient reports having recent onset breathlessness. The electrocardiogram (ECG) is presented below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• ECG shows- narrow complex tachycardia with irregular rhythm. Since P waves are seen, it rules out AF.
 
  • Different morphologies of P waves in ECG rules out sinus arrhythmia. All the above said features confirm MAT.
 
  • Absence of chest pain and significant ST elevations rules out acute myocardial infarction.
 
  • Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a cardiac arrhythmia caused by multiple sites of competing atrial activity. It is characterized by an irregular atrial rate greater than 100 beats per minute (bpm). Atrial activity is well organized, with at least 3 morphologically distinct P waves, irregular P-P intervals, and an isoelectric baseline between the P waves.
 
  • MAT is commonly seen in COPD patients. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1901, 1902.

questions.text: How can you tell the difference between cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Raised JVP, pulse pressure and muffled heart sounds along with pulsus paradoxus are seen in both cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax.

These are differentiated by auscultation for breath sounds, which are normal in cardiac tamponade but absent in tension pneumothorax patients.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 375.

questions.text: Which organ should be examined first during an emergency laparotomy for an intestinal obstruction to determine whether it is a small bowel or large colon obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cecum

While doing emergency laparotomy for an intestinal obstruction, cecum should be visualized first to confirm ,whether it's a small bowel or large bowel obstruction.

If caecum is collapsed, it is likely to be small bowel obstruction whereas it will be distended in large bowel obstruction. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1311.

questions.text: A thyroidectomy was performed on a patient who had hyperthyroidism. He appeared with thyroid storm symptoms two days later. What is most likely to be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 2) Inadequate preoperative preparation

Thyrotoxic crisis (storm) is an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism.
It most commonly occurs if a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy. 
During thyroid storm, an individual's heart rate, blood pressure, and body temperature can soar to dangerously high levels.

* [Extra Edge]: preoperative preparation
 
  • Traditional preparation aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid at operation.
  • Preparation is as an outpatient and only rarely is admission to hospital necessary on account of severe symptoms at presentation, failure to control the hyperthyroidism or non-compliance with medication. Care should be coordinated with endocrinology input.
  • Carbimazole 30–40 mg/day is the drug of choice for preparation. When euthyroid (after 8–12 weeks), the dose may be reduced to 5 mg 8-hourly or a ‘block and replace’ regime used.
  • In this case, the high dose of carbimazole is continued to inhibit T3 and T4 production and a maintenance dose of 0.1–0.15 mg thyroxine is given daily. The last dose of carbimazole may be given on the evening before surgery. Iodides are not used alone because, if the patient needs preoperative treatment, a more effective drug should be given.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 862.

choices.text: Massive transfusion of blood and blood products

questions.text: After RTA, a patient with massive haemorrhage arrives at the ER. What should not be done?
questions.solution:
Injudicious use of crystalloid during resuscitation has been shown to exacerbate the systemic insult in response to hemorrhagic shock, including worsened cardiac function, pulmonary complications, gastric dysmotility, abdominal compartment syndrome, coagulopathy, immunological and inflammatory dysfunction.
According to the Latest (10th edition) ATLS guidelines "Infusion of more than 1.5 liters of crystalloid has been associated with increased mortality."

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 16.

questions.text: A young man was taken to the ER after an RTA. 2 units of PRBC and 4 platelets were acquired from the blood bank due to the significant blood loss. There was only one accessible IV line. How will you proceed?
questions.solution:
Since platelets have the property of being stable at a temperature of 22-27 degree centigrade whereas PRBC will require cold storage at 4 degree centigrade, PRBC should be transfused first. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 16.

questions.text: Patient underwent a Road traffic accident and was placed on mechanical ventilation; he now opens his eyes upon being spoken to and moves all four of his limbs on his own. What will his GCS result be?
questions.solution:
Opening eyes on verbal command (E3), and moving all 4 limbs spontaneously (M6) is given a GCS score of 9.

Patients who are intubated are unable to speak, and their verbal scores cannot be assessed.
They are evaluated only based on eye-opening and motor scores, and the suffix T is added to their score to indicate intubation.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 365.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA and severe haemorrhage has been hospitalised. He need a huge amount of fluid transfusion. What type of IV cannula is preferred?
questions.solution:
The preferred IV cannula for the young patient with RTA requiring large amounts of fluids is Grey - 16G having the highest flow rate among the given options. 


Mnemonic for Colour coding of Cannula-
Oh Great God Please Bless Your People
Oh- Orange- 14G
Great- Grey- 16G
God- Green- 18G
Please- Pink- 20G
Bless- Blue- 22G
Your- Yellow- 24G
People- Purple- 26G



Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 17.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the OPD with copious diarrhea and dehydration. Which cannula can be used to ensure the flow of large amounts of fluids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) Grey

For quick fluid resuscitation in patients with dehydration, the grey cannula, which has a large bore (16 G) and a flow rate of 180 ml/min(maximum upto 240ml/min) , is the preferable cannula. 



Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 52.

questions.text: What colour is 16F Foley's catheter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Orange

It is a self-retaining urinary catheter made of latex. It has got a balloon near the tip into which distilled water is infused to make it self-retainable. Usually, Foley's catheter is kept for 7 days.
(F-French unit, Charriere unit, where each unit equals 0.33 mm). 16 F means circumference of the catheter is 16 mm. Diameter is one-third of circumference).

Fig: Catheter sizes are colored-coded at the balloon inflation site for easy identification

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 990.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion on 2nd intercostal space

questions.text: A patient presented with chest injuries and tachypnea (respiratory rate >40/minute), and after examination, he was found to have hypotension (BP- 90/60 mm Hg) and a hyperresonant note on the affected side. The following action will be taken:
questions.solution:
History of chest trauma with respiratory rate >40/minute, BP—90/60mm Hg and hyper-resonant note on involved side is highly suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Immediate decompression with large bore needle in mid clavicular line in 2nd intercostal space is the urgent treatment for this patient.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 373.

questions.text: What kind of breast examination technique is done if the physician palpated with the tips of all fingers save the thumb starting at 2 o'clock posterior palpated at three locations on line joining periphery to nipple. Then moved directly to 3 o'clock and returned centripetally while palpating at 3 locations on the line connecting periphery and nipple?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dial of Clock method

The described method of breast examination is known as "Dial of Clock" method.
In dial of clock method, palpation is performed in segmental manner until entire breast is examined with “pads of middle three fingers” (index, middle, and ring) with hand held in slightly bowed position.




Fig: Clinical breast examination

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 916.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most conspicuous  indicator of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Peau d’orange

Peau d'orange is the most conspicuous sign in breast cancer.

Peau d'orange (French for orange peel) is characterized by edema and pitting and results from blockage of lymphatic drainage with or without associated stromal infiltration. The most common cause of breast peau d'orange is inflammatory breast cancer. It makes the cancer a T4B disease. 





Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 815.

questions.text: What is the technique illustrated in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Sentinel lymph node biopsy

The technique depicted in the image is sentinel lymph node biopsy using methylene blue dye technique. 

Sentinel LN: First LN which receives lymph directly from tumor.

Sentinel node biopsy identifies the first few lymph nodes into which a tumor drains. The surgeon uses a harmless dye as in this image.  The nodes are removed and tested for signs of cancer. Sentinel node biopsy is a procedure to see if cancer has spread.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most beneficial in the following situations:
questions.solution:
Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful for carcinoma vulva among the given options.

Sentinel lymph node biopsy was discovered by Cavana. It is useful in vulva cancer, Melanoma and breast cancer. 

The inguinal lymph node status has been identified as the single most important factor in predicting mortality attributable to vulval cancer.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1576.

questions.text: What is the name of the given instrument is used for harvesting the graft from healthy area in split thickness skin graft?
questions.solution:
• The name of the given instrument is Humby knife, which is used for harvesting the graft from healthy area in split thickness skin graft.
  • The Humby – Braithwaite Dermatome (Skin Graft Knife) is used to collect a slice of healthy skin from donor site to perform a skin graft on a site with tissue loss.
  • Donor sites for the harvest of skin graft include the lumbar and gluteal regions (thick skin), the thighs, and the arms (thin skin).

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 317.

questions.text: What is the name of the given instrument?
questions.solution:
Name of the given instrument is chemoport, which is an implantable venous access device used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Chemoport is an implantable vascular access device lo provide repeated access to the vascular system for the delivery of medications, intravenous fluids, parenteral nutrition solutions and blood products.

Reference: Mittal GS, Sundriyal D, Naik NB, Sehrawat A. Totally Implantable Venous Access Device (Chemoport) in Oncology: Study of 168 Polyurethane Chemoport Catheter System. South Asian J Cancer. 2021 Dec 31;10(4):261-264. doi: 10.1055/s-0041-1739041. PMID: 34984207; PMCID: PMC8719977.

questions.text: What kind of flap-based technique is applied during pilonidal sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rhomboid flap 

Rhomboid flap-based procedure is used for pilonidal sinus surgery. The skin and subcutaneous fat to be removed is excised down to deep fascia, and a rhomboid area of specimen including pilonidal sinus and its all extensions are removed

Then flap is raised so that it includes skin, subcutaneous fat, and the fascia overlying gluteus maximus, rotated to cover midline rhomboid defect.


Fig: Rhomboid-Limberg flap for pilonidal sinus

Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 960.

choices.text: Pneumatic compression stocking to prevent the DVT

questions.text: What is the device listed below:
questions.solution:
The given device is pneumatic compression stocking, used to prevent DVT.

Intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) devices are used to help prevent blood clots in the deep veins of the legs. The devices use cuffs around the legs that fill with air and squeeze your legs. This increases blood flow through the veins of your legs and helps prevent blood clots.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 998.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple test for detecting Down syndrome during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Inhibin B
Inhibin A (not Inhibin B) is included in quadruple test.
 
First Trimester Second Trimester
• First trimester Combined
   (PAPP-A + Free beta HCG + NT)
• First trimester Triple Combined
   (PAPP-A + Free beta HCG + NT + AFP)
• First trimester Quad Combined
   (PAP-A + Free beta HCG + PIGF + AFP)		 • Triple marker
   (Free beta HCG + AFP + uE3)
• Quadruple marker
   (Free beta HCG + AFP + uE3 + Inhibin A)


 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 336.

questions.text: For emergency contraception, the following levonorgestrel dosage is used:
questions.solution:
Dose of levonorgestrel used for emergency contraception is 1.5 mg within 72 hours.

With progestin-only regimens,
  • 1.5 mg of levonorgestrel is taken,
  • either as a single, one-time 1.5-mg dose or
  • as two tablets, each containing 0.75 mg levonorgestrel. 


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 575.

questions.text: Endometrial hyperplasia with atypia was diagnosed in a postmenopausal woman after biopsy.What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Hysterectomy
 
  • Postmenopausal female with biopsy report as endometrial hyperplasia with atypia is having increased risk of malignancy. So the next line of management is hysterectomy.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia carries a reasonably high risk of progression to endometrial cancer if not adequately treated.
  • Simple hyperplasia without cytologic atypia carries a less than 1% chance of progression to cancer, whereas complex hyperplasia without atypia has 2% to 3% chance of progression to cancer. Thus these two entities are usually treated medically using progesterone therapy.
  • With cytologic atypia, simple hyperplasia and complex hyperplasia carry an 8% and 27% to 28% chance of progression to cancer, respectively.
  • With cytologic atypia, hysterectomy is usually the treatment of choice unless future fertility is still desired
  • In case of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, Progesterone is given. 



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 703.
Berek and Novak's Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 2363, 2364.

questions.text: How is the maternal mortality ratio expressed?
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio = (Number of maternal deaths / Number of live births) X 100,000.
 
  • Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a crucial indicator of maternal health, measuring the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period.
  • To calculate MMR, the total number of live births is used as the dominator.
  • This denominator reflects the population at risk of maternal deaths, as it includes all women who gave birth during the specified period.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was identified as having CIN-3. How will it be managed?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Colposcopy + LEEP






Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 417-419.

questions.text: When should a woman with gestational diabetes who is under control with insulin therapy terminate her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
NICE recommends that diabetes controlled on insulin should be terminated at 38 weeks.
 
  • However, The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2020c, 2021) suggests initiating such testing at 32 to 34 weeks’ gestation. With reassuring testing and no other complications, delivery is anticipated between 39 and 39+6 weeks.
  • Better answer should be 39 weeks. Since, 39 is not there in options, next best answer should be 38 weeks.
 
 Delivery:
• Timing of delivery depends on control
• If on insulin, the pregnancy is best terminated by 39>38 weeks
• If diet control is adequate then the pregnancy may be prolonged to term
• Mode of delivery depends on clinical judgement
• Diabetes itself is not an indication for caesarean
• Factors favoring an elective CS are
– Macrosomia
– Suspicion of cephalopelvic disproportion
– Malpresentation
– polyhydramnios



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1078.

questions.text: All are components of Active management of third stage of labor, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Uterine massage.
Uterine massage have now been removed from AMTSL.
Intermittent uterine tone assessment has replaced routine uterine massage.
Rest all are components of AMTSL 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 506-508.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for a vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Cystoscopy is considered the IOC for vesicovaginal fistula. 





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 383.
Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 577.

questions.text: The growth of granulosa cells prior to ovulation is dependent on:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. FSH
 
  • The major functions of granulosa cells include the production of sex steroids, as well as myriad growth factors thought to interact with the oocyte during its development.
  • The sex steroid production begins with follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary, stimulating granulosa cells to convert androgens (coming from the thecal cells) to estradiol by aromatase during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • However, after ovulation the granulosa cells turn into granulosa lutein cells that produce progesterone.



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 352.

questions.text: Which of the following is not reversible long acting contraceptives?
questions.solution:
• Laparoscopic tubal ligation is an irreversible method of contraception and is the most common method of preventing pregnancy.
 
  • Copper-T and LNG-IUS are intrauterine devices whereas implanon is a hormone releasing implant. All these methods are reversible.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 583.

questions.text: Except for__________, all are possible indicators of choriocarcinoma after hydatidiform mole:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. More number of theca lutein cysts
 
  • Increased number of theca lutein cyst is NOT an indicator of Choriocarcinoma. Increased size or persistence of theca lutein cysts indicate Choriocarcinoma.
  • Suburethral nodules are seen in metastasis of choriocarcinoma.

Risk factors for malignant conversion for Hydatidiform mole are:
  1. Age <20 years or >= 40 years
  2. Parity >=3
  3. Previous history of Molar pregnancy
  4. Size of uterus >20 wks POG
  5. Serum beta-hCG >1,00,000 IU/ml
  6. Persistence or increased size of Theca lutein cysts

Indicators of malignant change are:
  • Increased vascularity
  • Suburethral nodules
  • Uterine (Myometrial) nodules



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 241, 242.
Berek and Novak's Gynecology, 16th edition, Page no 2774.

questions.text: Young female with a history of spontaneous abortion and secondary amenorrhea . Her FSH 6 IU/ml. What is the most probable cause of amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Uterine synechiae. It develops after D and C where later fibrous bands of Uterine synechiae develops, this is known as Asherman syndrome. 
As this is a case of secondary Amenorrhea with normal FSH levels , ovarian failure and pituitary failure are ruled out.
In ovarian failure, FSH > 25 IU/ ml
In Pituitary failure FSH < 5 IU/ ml
In pregnancy due to high estrogen in body FSH < 0.1 IU/ ml


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology,17th edition, Page no 153, 154. 
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 374, 375.

questions.text: A patient with Placenta grade 3, 35+3 weeks pregnancy, AFI=5 and absent end diastolic flow in Doppler; What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Talk with pediatrician and immediate termination

The patient has already crossed 34 weeks and Doppler is showing absent end diastolic flow. Since, lung maturity is attained by 34 weeks, there is no need to wait for dexamethasone coverage.

Management: Immediate TOP by Cesarean section

UA PI>p95

Reverse Aol		 Biweekly 34 weeks CS

DV-PI>p95		 1-2 days 32 weeks CS
IV High-suspicion fetal acidosis DV reverse a flow cCTG <3 ms FHR decelerations 12 h 26 Weeks** CS



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th edition, Page no 219-222.

questions.text: Which is the instrument shown?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Esophageal temperature probe
 
  • Esophageal temperature probes are used to monitor core body temperatures in patients receiving anesthesia. The probe is advanced either through the nasal passage or oral cavity, before following a similar path to a nasogastric tube.
  • Other images: Pulmonary artery catheter, also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter or right heart catheter, is a balloon-tipped catheter that is inserted into a pulmonary artery in a procedure known as pulmonary artery catheterization or right heart catheterization.

   

  • NAVA catheter – Neurally adjusted ventilatory assist is a mode of mechanical ventilation. NAVA delivers assistance in proportion to and in synchrony with the patient's respiratory efforts, as reflected by an electrical signal. This signal represents the electrical activity of the diaphragm, the body's principal breathing muscle.


   



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1094.

Er A, Qureshi P, Knipe H, Esophageal temperature probe. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 18 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-94366. URL: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/oesophageal-temperature-probe?lang=us

questions.text: A five-year-old female child has odd coarse facial traits, an oversized head, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, a protruding abdomen, breathing problems caused by obstructive sleep apnea, and thickened heart valves. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Peculiar facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, protuberant abdomen, breathing difficulty with obstructive sleep apnea, and cardiac valve thickening are suggestive of Mucopolysaccharidoses. 
  • Since the child is a female - it cannot be Hunter's disease since Hunter is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. 
  • The likely diagnosis is Hurler's syndrome and it is characterized by a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme. 




Other options

Option 2 - Hunter's is also a MPS with similar features (coarse facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, protuberant abdomen, cardiac valve thickening etc ) but since its X-linked recessive - its seen only in Boys, not girls. Hunter also does NOT have corneal clouding. 

Option 3 -  Fragile X disorder - The most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and has features which include Long face, large ears, macroorchidism in males with developmental delay. It does not have coarse facial features or cardiac valve thickening. 

Option 4 - Tay Sachs occurs due to Hexosaminidase A deficiency and has neurodegeneration, developmental regression, hyperacuisis, cherry-red spot on macula but no organomegaly. 





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 811,812

questions.text: BCG offers the greatest protection against:
questions.solution:
BCG is maximally protective against CNS and disseminated tuberculosis.
 
Meta-analysis of the trials regarding effectiveness of BCG vaccination has shown that BCG is 50% effective in preventing pulmonary tuberculosis while the effectiveness against meningeal and disseminated tuberculosis is seen to be 50-80%.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 232.

questions.text: Which of the following is the maximum steroid produced by the fetal adrenal?
questions.solution:
• The steroid produced in the maximum quantity by the fetal adrenal glands is DHEA-S.
  • The fetal adrenal gland is formed around 8-10 weeks.
  • Initially, the glands produce cortisol which acts to suppress ACTH production from the pituitary. During this phase, the gonadal development in males and females is taking place and such an action is necessary.
  • In the second trimester, cortisol production decreases and DHEA and DHEA Sulphate are produced in large quantities. The placenta uses these for the production of estrone and estradiol. 
  • In the third trimester again, cortisol production is increased but the hormone produced in maximum quantity stays DHEA-S.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2959

choices.text: Turner syndrome with the webbed neck is more likely to develop CVS defects than non-webbed neck
Coarctation of the aorta is more likely in non-webbed neck

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Turner's syndrome is correct?
questions.solution:
• Turner Syndrome with a Webbed neck is 3 times more likely to develop CVS abnormalities than a non-webbed neck.
  • The most common CVS defect in Turner's syndrome is the Bicuspid aortic valve followed by the Coarctation of the Aorta.
  • Turner syndrome is typically characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, and other physical abnormalities, but intelligence is usually normal. There may be some learning difficulties, but overall cognitive ability is not significantly impaired. 
  • Hence among options 1 and 3, 1 is better answer than option 3.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 637,638

questions.text: Calculate the Silverman Anderson score in a preterm newborn who has audible grunting, marked chest and xiphoid retractions, and see-saw movements but No nasal flaring.
questions.solution:
The Silverman-Anderson score of the child is 8 - option 2.
 
Findings with the score:
 
Audible grunt - 2
Nasal flare - 0
See-saw upper chest movement - 2
Xiphoid recessions-2
Lower chest retractions-2

Total = 2+0+2+2+2= 8.
 
The preterm newborn's respiratory distress is measured by a score called the Silverman-Anderson score. Five features are observed for the index case, and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2. An increase in the score represents a higher respiratory distress.



INTERPRETATION OF SILVERMAN ANDERSON SCORE
  • 0 → No respiratory distress
  • 1–3 → Mild distress - Give oxygen
  • 4–6 → Moderate distress - Give CPAP
  • 7–10 → Severe respiratory distress - Intubate and Mechanical ventilation

Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10313036/

questions.text: A sick intubated neonate is having bilateral jerks of both right/left and upper limbs with some occasional twitching of the neck as well. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Multifocal clonic seizure is the most likely seizure in a patient who has bilateral jerks of both their right and left upper limbs as well as occasional neck twitching."
  •  Several bodily sections are involved in multifocal clonic seizures, which are migratory in character.
  • The migration has a non-Jacksonian pattern, meaning that jerks in the left arm can be associated with jerks in the right leg."

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3111

questions.text: Identify the well-circumscribed osteolytic lesion in the calcaneum of an 8-year-old child with pigmented deposits using histological images:
questions.solution:
Haemophilic pseudotumors are rare complications of hemophilia consisting of a progressive cystic swelling of muscle and/or bone due to repeated bleeding, occurring in <2% of hemophiliacs as seen in this image. In histology it shows a dense capsule which contains clots, bony debri. 


Reference-: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7191985/

questions.text: What is the earliest indication of compartment syndrome of the leg?
questions.solution:
• Pain on passive stretching are early indicators whereas paraesthesia, paralysis and pulselessness occur late.
  • It is important to thoroughly and regularly assess skin sensations. Muscles which are ischemic are very sensitive to stretching. Stretching should be used to test the muscles, which may be tender, if the limb is excessively painful, swollen, or tense.
  • There is increased pain in the calf or forearm when the toes or fingers are passively hyperextended.
  • Pulses may still be felt and the skin may not be pale in compartment syndrome because the ischemia occurs at the capillary level.
  • Definitive management is fasciotomy. 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 47

choices.text: Superior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during flexion
Superior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during extension
Inferior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during flexion
Inferior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during extension

questions.text: Where does the hypertrophied scar or interposition of soft tissue cause patellar clunk syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patellar clunk syndrome is interposition of soft tissue or hypertrophic scar at the superior pole of patella and impinging on the femoral component during extension from flexion position.



Reference-: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7732733/

questions.text: What is this picture depicting?
questions.solution:
Swan neck deformity of the finger proximal interphalangeal(PIP) joint is hyperextended, and the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint is flexed.





    



Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 288

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is seen with a fever and a 4 month-old wound on his right leg that has been draining pus.
The given X-ray of this patient has a labelled structure; identify it:
questions.solution:
• In the question, Arrow points to the sequestrum.
  • A bony sequestrum is a piece of devascularised bone that becomes separated from the remainder of the bone in chronic osteomyelitis and acts as a nidus for ongoing infection.
  • It appears hyperdense as compared to surrounding bones to due absence of demineralization from the incoming blood. 

   



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 172

questions.text: An X-ray of a 7-year-old is shown here. Which deformity is it?
questions.solution:
• The given pelvic radiograph shows decrease in the neck-shaft angle of bilateral femur-s/o coxa vara. 
  • The angle of inclination is normally between 120-135 degrees, but in Coxa vara, it is reduced to less than 120 degrees.
  • This can be caused by a variety of factors, including congenital deformities, trauma, or infection.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 323

questions.text: Identify the lytic lesion near the radius's end:
questions.solution:
• The lesion shown in the question is a giant cell tumour or osteoclastoma.
  • Giant cell tumour can be seen in the given image as an epiphyseal lytic lesion in the radius with a "soap bubble" appearance. An osteoclastoma tumour always touches the edge of a joint.
  • In a Giant-cell Tumour, Radiolucent region bordered by a subchondral bone plate is seen which is located eccentrically at the end of a long bone in X-rays. The centre of the lesion occasionally resembles a soap bubble as a result of ridging of the surrounding bones.
  • A cystic lesion in mature bone that extends all the way to the subchondral plate is so distinctive that the diagnosis is rarely in question.
  • Osteochondroma is an extension or outgrowth of the growth plate which is usually pedunculated.

Important d/d is Aneurysmal Bone Cysts, it has similar appearance but occurs before growth plate fusion.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 238

questions.text: Following a spinal shock, the following reflex is the first to return:
questions.solution:
• The first reflex to disappear as well as return following spinal shock is bulbocavernous reflex ( S2S3S4 )
  • It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis or clitoris or by tapping the penile or clitoral shaft. The reflex causes a contraction of the bulbocavernosus muscle, which results in a downward movement of the anus and the base of the penis or clitoris.
  • This is because the reflex arc for the bulbocavernosus reflex is relatively short and involves only a few spinal segments.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 276

questions.text: Phosphaturia and osteomalacia are symptoms of which metabolic disorder?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, fibrosarcoma is known to cause tumor induced rickets which is charatcerized by osteomalacia and phosphaturia. 

Remember, the most common tumor associated with oncogenic rickets is hemangiopericytoma. 

Other important examples to remember- hemangioendothelioma, osteosarcoma, osteoblastoma, carcinoma breast. 


Reference :https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560759/

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought in with complaints of photophobia and bilateral proptosis along with eye watering. Which medical diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Watering of eyes along with bilateral proptosis and photophobia in a 2 year old child is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

It is seen between birth and the age of 3-4 years.

Clinical features:

The affected eye is enlarged with a hazy cornea.
Increased size of eyeball (Buphthalmos).
Photophobia is the earliest symptoms due to corneal edema
It should be noted that the earliest sign is Corneal Haze (Ground glass appearance)
Watering of eyes
At a later stage, due to rupture of Descemet's membrane, more discrete corneal opacities are seen
Blue eyes due to scleral thinning.


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: Sturge-Weber syndrome's most prevalent ocular symptom is
questions.solution:
The most common ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome is glaucoma.
 
Studies have reported that it is seen in 30%-70% of the patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome and can be present at birth or may develop later in life. The most common age of onset is 6 years.

In patients with Sturge–Weber syndrome or its variants, presentation at birth is associated with a gonioscopic appearance of the anterior chamber angle that cannot be differentiated from that of primary congenital glaucoma



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1107.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man arrived with right eye pain and watering that had been present for 36 hours. A 3 x 2 cm corneal ulcer measuring raised borders, fluffy hyphae, finger-like projections, and minor hypopyon in the cornea is discovered during examination. What organism is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Aspergillus
 
  • Pain and watering in the eye for 36 hours with presence of corneal ulcer having elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger-like projections and minimal hypopyon is highly suggestive of fungal corneal ulcer.
  • Among the options, Aspergillus is the only fungus.
  • Fungal corneal ulcers are commonly caused due to injury by vegetative material. These ulcers have feathery borders. Along with this, satellite lesions, ciliary congestion and a Wessely immune ring can be seen around the ulcer.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 227.

questions.text: What angle does the largest letter in the Snellen chart subtend on the eye of someone reading it at a distance of 6 metres?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. 50 minutes
 
  • The largest letter on the Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes when viewed from a distance of 60 meters.
  • Visual acuity refers to the eye's spatial resolution or its capacity to distinguish between two points.
  • The Snellen chart is utilized for assessing visual acuity. On this chart, the letters decrease in size as you move downward, and they should be read at distances of 60, 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, 5, and 4 meters, respectively. At these distances, the letters subtend a visual angle of 5 minutes. Thus, the largest letter visible at 60 meters subtends a visual angle of 5 minutes in the eye.

Visual acuity of the largest letter is 6/60. The minimum angle of resolution( MAR) at 60 meteres =1 minute. The MAR at 6 meters will be 60/6=10minutes.
Therefore, The angle subtended by the letter: 5x10=50 minutes.






Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: Given below is the image of the patient who presented with diplopia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given images shows ptosis and down & out left eye ball in the primary gaze. There are defects in all eye movements with the exception of abduction (this shows maintained lateral rectus function). Such a presentation suggests oculomotor (third) nerve palsy. Down and out eye: 3rd nerve palsy.

Option 1: Lateral rectus palsy: Shows restriction in movement of abduction of ipsilateral eye. Occurs due to Abducens nerve palsy.

Option 2: Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia: Injury to MLF. Shows normal primary gaze. There is restriction of adduction and adducting saccades of the ipsilateral eye. On attempted lateral gaze, away from the side of the lesion, the abducting eye overshoots the target (dysmetria), giving the appearance of dissociated (disconjugate) nystagmus.

Option 4: Trochlear nerve palsy: Weakness of the superior oblique muscle allows unopposed action of its direct antagonist, the inferior oblique muscle, which results in an ipsilateral hypertropia and excyclotorsion. The classic sign of unilateral fourth nerve palsy is a contralateral head tilt (an ocular torticollis). 


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no: 927, 1228-1233.

questions.text: These eyeglasses are worn for:
questions.solution:
The given image shows bifocal glasses. Bifocal glasses are most commonly used for presbyopic individuals who have difficulty in both near and far vision. Presbyopia is an age related defect of vision caused due to decreased power of accommodation.
  • Executive bifocals are used for pediatric pseudophakia.
  • It is rarely used in Aphakia.
  • The image shows straight bifocals which are used in presbyopia.

questions.text: A patient went to the OPD complaining of  rotatory vertigo after waking up in the morning caused  by head movement. What is your medical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of the patient who complains of rotatory vertigo in the morning caused by change in head position is suggestive of Benign Paroxysmal positional vertigo.
 
This condition is caused by displacement of calcium crystals most commonly into the posterior semicircular canal which leads to vertigo on change in head position as the calcium crystals get distributed and stimulate the posterior semicircular canal.

questions.solution:
In the given image, the patient is suffering from oropharyngeal candidiasis, which should be treated by antifungal agents such as Clotrimazole troches or Nystatin or fluconazole.
 
Oropharyngeal candidiasis, also known as thrush, is commonly caused by Candida albicans. It is commonly seen in neonates, immunocompromised patients (especially those suffering from AIDS. It is also seen in recipients of prolonged antibiotic or glucocorticoid therapy.

questions.text: Using histopathology, determine the disease as displayed in the figure:
questions.solution:
The biopsy reveals a suprabasal split, the basal epidermis has a row-of-tombstones, and acantholytic cells are seen within the split. These findings are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.
 
  • A basal split caused by necrotic basal keratinocytes is seen in TEN.
  • Mycosis fungoides and lepromatous leprosy have an almost normal epidermis without any splits.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman has had two months with asymptomatic dome-shaped tiny lesions on her forehead. She has a daughter, age 2, who has comparable lesions.
What is the cause of the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The lesions in the given picture on the forehead are pearly white papules and with a history of transmission to her daughter, the most likely diagnosis is Molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by the poxvirus.
  • In molluscum contagiosum, typical lesions which are pink or skin coloured in the form of an umbilicated papule containing a greyish central plug. It is seen commonly in children.
  • The face and genitals are commonly involved and the face is most commonly involved in children, in whom the groin and genitals are not affected, which are usually involved in sexually active adults.

questions.text: The following itching lesion has been present on a young man for one month. Except for ____  all of the following genera can result in this form of lesion:
questions.solution:
• The lesions shown in the image are suggestive of Tinea cruris, commonly known as Jack itch, is a dermatophytosis of the groin area typically caused by Trichophyton rubrum. 
  • A class of fungus known as dermatophytes includes ringworms which, under moist conditions, can infect and thrive solely on dead keratin, the outermost layer of skin, hair, and nails.
  • It belongs to three genera Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton.

questions.text: Which is the ideal position for Ryle’s tube insertion?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Sitting with neck flexed
 
  • If the patient is conscious, the best position for inserting the Ryle's tube is sitting with the neck flexed at 45 degrees angle and patient is asked to take sips of water by straw. 
  • The best position for comatose individuals is supine with the neck flexed. 

The steps for inserting a Ryles tube include: 
  • Position: A conscious patient should be Sitting with neck flexed.
  • Check placement: Ask the patient to speak to assess the tube's position. You can also use pH paper to measure the aspirate pH. 
  • Secure: Tape the tube to the patient's cheek to hold it in place. 
  • Preparation: Put on gloves, gown, and face shield. Check the nostrils for obstructions and patency. Place a towel over the patient's chest. 
  • Anesthesia: Spray a topical anesthetic in the nostril and pharynx at least five minutes before insertion. 
  • Lubricate: Apply a water-soluble lubricant to the tip of the tube. 
  • Insert: Gently insert the tube into the nose, aiming toward the earlobe. 
  • Advance: Ask the patient to take sips of water through a straw while advancing the tube. 
It's important to verify the tube's placement before each feeding to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia. 

Confirmation of correct position of Ryles tube:
  1. Auscultation of epigastrium while injecting bolus of air through it
  2. Chest radiography
  3. pH measurement
  4. Ultrasound


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 336.

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about the distinction between adult and kid resuscitation is correct?
questions.solution:
Ventricular dysrhythmias are uncommon in children is the CORRECT statement
 
  • Ventricular dysrhythmias are not a common cause of cardiac arrest in children and it is more commonly caused due to hypoxia induced Bradycardia.
  • This is why rescue breaths are important in the case of pediatric resuscitation. Most cardiac arrests in pediatric cases are caused by respiratory failures which is why ventilation is given importance during resuscitation procedure. Ventilation is same as adults (30:2)
  • Infant myocardium more refractory to hypoxia because of Higher glycolytic activity, increased myocardial reserve and higher levels of HbF


Reference: Tintinalli's Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide, 9th edition, Page no 679, 681, 686.

questions.text: Which of the following studies does not include the use of ionizing radiation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: MRI



MRI does not use ionizing radiation as in an MRI, magnetic fields are used for imaging.
 
This is why there is no radiation exposure during MRI as X-rays are not involved.
CT scan, Mammography and Angiography use x-ray.

questions.text: Determine the diagnosis in provided X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Penumoperitoneum.

The given X-Ray shows gas under right and left hemidiaphragm as well as beneath central tendon of diaphragm suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. 

Most common cause of pneumoperitoneum in adults- Hollow viscus perforation
Most common cause in neonates- Necrotizing enterocolitis
Best X-Ray projection- Erect chest X-Ray PA view
Investigation of choice- CT Abdomen 

The various named signs in pneumoperitoneum are as follows:



The given chest X-ray is clearly showing gas under the right dome of the diaphragm, which is  suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.
 
The term Pneumoperitoneum refers to gas within the peritoneal cavity. The most common cause of pneumoperitoneum is laparoscopic surgery.

The most sensitive radiograph to demonstrate pneumoperitoneum is an erect chest X-ray.
 
Causes of pneumoperitoneum include:

Perforation of the GI tract (caused due to Peptic Ulcers, Inflammation, infarction etc).
Penetrating abdominal injury.
Iatrogenic
Peritonitis with gas formation
Pneumothorax with pleuroperitoneal fistula.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 137.

questions.text: Where is the empty thecal sac sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Arachnoiditis.

Arachnoiditis is defined as inflammation within the subarachnoid space which leads to formation of organizing exudates and thereby, permanent intradural adhesions. 

Causes:
  • Most common cause-Iatrogenic 
  • Accidental trauma 
  • Spinal subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Intradural infection 

Radiographic features- MRI is the most sensitive modality to delineate the findings. 

MRI
  • Most commonly seen in the lumbar region of spinal cord where the cauda equina usually floats in ample CSF.
  • This causes the nerve roots to become adherent to each other and to theca, causing obstruction of the lower subarachnoid space. 
  • Empty thecal sac sign or empty sac sign: 
    • Thecal sac appears empty on MRI of the lumbar spine due to central clumping of nerve roots.  
    • Best seen on T2-weighted images. 
    • It is diagnostic of adhesive arachnoiditis. 
Three morphological patterns of arachnoiditis described on the basis of imaging are: 
  • Type I: nerve roots clumped together and distorted
  • Type II: nerve roots adherent to the theca resulting in an empty thecal sac sign
  • Type III: nerve roots and theca clumped together into a single soft tissue mass centrally within the spinal canal 
The empty thecal sac sign or empty sac sign is when the thecal sac appears empty on MRI of the lumbar spine, best seen on T2-weighted images.
If the empty thecal sac sign is present, a diagnosis of adhesive arachnoiditis can be made.
Adhesive arachnoiditis is best seen on T2-weighted images. It can be observed throughout the subarachnoid space but is most commonly seen in the lumbar region.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 1371.

questions.text: Identify the type of investigation done on the given X-ray image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Myelography
 
  • Imaging procedure performed to evaluate the subarachnoid spaces within the spinal canal. 
  • Fluoroscopic, CT or MR imaging is performed after intrathecal injection of contrast media, usually under fluoroscopic or CT guidance.
  • Only contrast agent approved by FDA for intrathecal injection in order to perform myelography-Iohexol. 
  • Although conventional (i.e. fluoroscopic) myelography has been largely supplanted by modern CT and (especially) MRI of the spine, it remains a useful tool in the evaluation of spondylosis.
  • CT myelography is useful in patients who cannot undergo MRI and CSF leaks/fistulas are suspected.
  • MR Myelography may also provide evaluation without the need for intrathecal gadolinium by utilizing specific fluid-sensitive acquisition techniques.
The investigation shown in the image is myelography.
 
Myelography is a radiographic investigation of the spinal canal which is used for the diagnosis of space occupying and obstructive lesions. A contrast agent is injected into subarachnoid space via lumbar puncture for the imaging.

Nowadays, MRI has replaced myelography, because myelography is invasive and provides less information.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1232, 1233.

questions.text: Identify the pathology on the given X-ray image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Cervical rib.

The given chest X-Ray shows bilateral cervical ribs arising from transverse process of seventh cervical vertebra. 

Cervical ribs:
  • Supernumerary or accessory ribs arising from seventh cervical vertebra.
  • Bilateral in ~ 80% of cases, asymmetric and more common in females. 
  • Anterior end may attach to the first rib, the sternum or the cartilage of the first rib
  • Anterior end can be in the form of a fibrous band or it may have no anterior attachment.
  • Majority are asymptomatic.
  • Clinical importance- Can cause thoracic outlet syndrome. 
The given image is showing a condition known as Cervical rib.
 
Cervical ribs arise from the 7th cervical vertebrae and are more commonly seen on the right side. The patient may present with a lump and tenderness in the supraclavicular fossa and the diagnosis is made using a chest X-ray.
 
Treatment modalities include, Sling exercise for mild cases while In severe cases, Scalenotomy (resection of scalenus anterior muscles) is done. In troublesome cases, the cervical rib is removed.



Reference: Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar, 5th edition, Page no 365.

questions.text: Which of the following provisions of the 2017 Mental Health Act are not based on the WHO mental health gap action ?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Screening family members
 
  • The goal of the Mental Health Gap Action Program (MHGAP) is to provide care, raise awareness, offer psychosocial support, build communication, and administer medicine to people with mental, neurological, and substance use disorders.
  • Screening of family members is not a part of MHGAP.
  • The Mental Health Act 2017 includes provisions to ensure that people with mental disorders are involved in decisions about their care and treatment, and that they receive information about their condition and treatment options in a way that they can understand. 
  • The Mental Health Act 2017 includes provisions to promote social support for people with mental disorders, including access to community-based services and support networks.


Reference: The Mental Health Care Act (MHCA) 2017 https://www.indiacode.nic.in/handle/123456789/2249
Chadda, Rakesh K. “Influence of the new mental health legislation in India.” BJPsych international vol. 17,1 (2020): 20-22. doi:10.1192/bji.2019.18
WHO Mental health Gap action Programme (mhGAP) https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241596206

questions.text: What is the SPIKES protocol used for?
questions.solution:

SPIKES protocol is used for communication with patients/attendants regarding bad news.
 
The spikes protocol includes:
 
S-SETTING UP the Interview
P-Assessing the patient's PERCEPTION
I-Obtaining the patient's INVITATION
K-Giving KNOWLEDGE and information to the patient
E-Addressing the patient's EMOTIONS with EMPATHIC responses.
S-STRATEGY and SUMMARY

questions.text: The mental healthcare act states that a person who is not a minor and has a known psychiatric disease or is receiving treatment may choose the caregiver and the course of therapy. What is it known as?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Advance directive  
 
  • According to the Mental Healthcare Act 2017, a person who is not a minor and has a known psychiatric disease or is receiving treatment may choose his/her caretaker and the type of care. This is known as an Advance directive.
  • Advance directives are preferences and decisions for medical treatment when a patient's condition is thought to be terminal.
